turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi there, it's Doctor Smith from Babylon.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, hi, Doctor Smith.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi there. Could you give me your full name, date of birth, and your, the first line of your address, please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Your full name, date of birth, and your address, please? Yeah, OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, my name is Barbara <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and my date of birth, fourth October, nineteen eighty four.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And address fifty <UNIN/> Avenue.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Are you in a private place so you can have a confidential consultation today?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I've just been <UNIN/> for the past couple of days. I've been having this serious diarrhoea and this really,

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Giving me trouble.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So when did it start?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>It was</UNSURE> three days ago.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And when you say diarrhoea, what do you mean by that? Is it watery or just loose?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It's, it's, it's very loose but it started as being very watery.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how many times are you going to the toilet?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I lost count, um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Today alone, I've been at least four time.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And any, any high temperatures? Are you feeling feverish?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, I've been running a serious temperature. I'm literally boiling.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you checked your temperature with a thermometer?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, 'cause I've not got one but like, to the touch, I'm, like, literally roasting.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, and any nausea or vomiting?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, I've been throwing up. I can't keep to, uh, I can't seem to be able to keep anything in me. Not even water, not even my tea, not even any liquid stuff. I've just been throwing up everything.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And when, when were you last sick?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I was sick just after trying, uh, trying to have breakfast this morning, so maybe about two hours ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And have you been passing water OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I've been, I've been, yeah, urinating OK. Is that what you mean, like?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, urinating, yeah. Any, and what sort of color is the urine?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: To be honest, I <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> have a look so I really couldn't say.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And when did you last pass urine, do you think?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> an hour ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And any blood in the stool or in the urine that you've noticed?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No blood.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any episodes like this before? How's your bowels normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry, I didn't catch that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How is your bowels normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ah, ah, my, my bowels is normally fine. I would normally go to the toilet every day. You know, in the morning, just once, yeah, and that's fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any episodes of diarrhoea or constipation normally?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And <UNIN/> is there anything you think might have triggered this off? Have you been abroad anywhere?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, but then, um, my, um my brother, um, has actually been having similar symptoms, um, for the past, um, few days as well, and he does say like everyone in school's got this so, I, I don't know, that might, that might be something.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So you've been in contact with him, have you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, and any other medical problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you had any other symptoms at the moment, like rash?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no rash, no, nothing that, um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, any surgery before, or abdominal problems, or any other medical issues?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, apart from the fact that this one is giving me abdominal pains, no previous abdominal pains before. Obviously I get the odd, um,  you know, menstrual cramps and all that but, you know, that's, you know, that comes and goes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And whereabouts is the pain that you're getting?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, it's kind of like towards my navel area, like I can't touch my navel area. It's just so sore. And it gets, yeah, it's almost like the center of my navel.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and does the pain come and go?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, it does come. When it comes, I feel this strong urge to go to the, to the loo, and then <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> and sort of like comes again, it comes and.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and do you take any medication regularly?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, I, I take my, my vitamins, <UNIN/> vitamin D, every day. That's about, that's about all that I regularly take.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And have you got a normal diet?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, <UNIN/> I eat well, normally.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. Do you smoke or drink alcohol?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, I don't smoke, but, you know, I have a pint from time to time.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And do you take any other drugs?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. Like I said, I only take, um, vitamins. And for my menstrual cramps, when they come, maybe I might take a, a, an ibuprofen just to ease the pain, but.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And when was, when was your last period?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, two weeks ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Are you on any contraception?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you having regular sexual intercourse?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and what's your job?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, um, uh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, uh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: A graphics designer.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you had to miss work because of this problem?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, yes, I've had to actually work from home today. I'm working from home today because I can't, I can't be out for work. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And who do you live with at home?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I live with my brother and my mum.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, um, have you tried anything yourself for this problem?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well, I've tried a home remedy. Um, I've tried the, the, uh, ORS, you know, thing I bought from my, my local, my local, uh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: What? Could you just repeat that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: The ORS, the, the salt sugar ORS, um, um, mix, the salt sugar mix.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how often have you been taking that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I've taken that, I've taken that, like, um, three times a day for the past two days.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, and do you feel like your symptoms are easing off, or getting worse, or <UNIN/> ?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> I, I, I they're not getting any better, 'cause like I said, I've been, I've been vomiting literally everything I take, so, so I doubt that even that had, had the chance to work.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I mean, it sounds like, because your brother's had a similar thing, it sounds like it might be some, an infectious gastroenteritis that you've got, which is usually caused by a virus. But, it can be from something you've eaten, as well. Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If the symptoms, they do normally start to settle by themselves with the oral rehydration salts. Um, if the symptoms are continuing to get worse, the key thing is that we want to make sure that you're hydrated enough.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, sometimes you do require certain medication to help this, if it's, sometimes if it's caused by a bacteria. Um, what I would say, probably worth as it's been going on for a few days and you feel like it's not starting to ease off.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I think it's probably important to get a sample of the stool, so we can make sure that you haven't got a nasty bacterial infection which needs specific treatment.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and we should also check that you're not getting dehydrated, because if you're, if you're not keeping fluid down, then you can get dehydrated.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, so.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, how, how do I, how do I get myself hydrated when I'm not able to even, like, drink water? I'm throwing up everything.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. So you need to carry on with your rehydration salts, and just have very small amounts. It's a positive sign that you passed urine an hour ago. So, you're obviously still, um, hydrated enough to pass urine.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But we, um, we should see you so that we can check your hydration and, um, get that sample sent off as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: 'cause if, if, if you come into the clinic, you can send that sample off straightaway. Otherwise, we would have to post it out to you which would take time.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh, OK. So, when can I come to the clinic to have this done?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, so we can, we can make you an urgent appointment, um, and then you can, you can get the sample sent off and we can check your hydration. Um, but if, in the meantime, you're feeling more unwell, then we would get you seen urgently in A and E.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So you can call us back in the meantime.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. So, what I'll do is, yeah. If you could, please book me the appointment and, um, yeah, I'll see how I feel, um, for the end of the day. Hopefully I don't need to go to the A and E, and, um <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> .

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. If you keep drinking, keep going with the rehydration salts. Just tiny sips constantly, to <UNIN/> so that your stomach doesn't get overfilled and, and you vomit, so just tiny, tiny sips but just keep going with it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and just have very simple food, if you're gonna have anything, like toast or biscuit or something really light like that. Avoid, um, fruit, vegetables, uh, milk, anything like that, which might just make it worse.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So you'll have to book an appointment through the support line.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, please.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. We'll do that for you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, take care.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Thanks, bye.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>
